Title: Linking forum posts -comparch-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Just an idea: What if an instruction changes the instruction that follows the modifying instruction: [$pc+4] <- some_instruction_code Is this a data hazard or a control hazard? Do modern processors really have logic protecting from this? (I assume that the processor is in some super user mode to allow such modification).
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Most ISAs, including x86, do not allow direct access to the program counter for writing. \xA0The program counter can only be read but not written directly, even in privileged mode. \xA0Therefore, this situation does not arise. However, you can achieve the effect you are asking about through something like a jump register (jr) instruction. \xA0You can write any address (remember the program counter holds an address pointing to an instruction, not the instruction itself which seems unclear from your statement using 'some_instruction_code') to a register, and then use that register as an operand to the jump register instruction. \xA0This causes the address in the register to be written to the program counter. \xA0However, in this case, this would be a control hazard, since the hazard is caused by a control transfer instruction modifying the control flow in the program. The program counter is implicitly written to in other instruction like jump register, such as jump, jump and link, branch, etc. \xA0These cases would also be considered control hazards. \xA0You may encounter a data hazard, in the jump register example, between the jump register instruction reading a register and a previous instruction that wrote to that same register. \xA0However, this would cause the jump register instruction to stall, not the instruction following the jump register. Hope that helps

However, you can achieve the effect you are asking about through something like a jump register (jr) instruction. \xA0You can write any address (remember the program counter holds an address pointing to an instruction, not the instruction itself which seems unclear from your statement using 'some_instruction_code') to a register, and then use that register as an operand to the jump register instruction. \xA0This causes the address in the register to be written to the program counter. \xA0However, in this case, this would be a control hazard, since the hazard is caused by a control transfer instruction modifying the control flow in the program. The program counter is implicitly written to in other instruction like jump register, such as jump, jump and link, branch, etc. \xA0These cases would also be considered control hazards. \xA0You may encounter a data hazard, in the jump register example, between the jump register instruction reading a register and a previous instruction that wrote to that same register. \xA0However, this would cause the jump register instruction to stall, not the instruction following the jump register. Hope that helps

Title: Linking forum posts -comparch-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
The prof. explains a hypothetical deadlock (basically a 'hang' situation) when the feed back travels back and forward in the pipeline i.e. a prev instruction (n) depends on the next instruction (n+1) and vice versa simultaneously. However I cannot think of any instruction where instr \xA0n would depend on instr n+1 its always the other way round i.e. instr n+1 depends on instr n. Maybe I am missing in understanding the deadlock situation? Anyone got this deadlock example?\xA0
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
An example of this situation is as follows: Lets say the architecture has a unified instruction and data memory. \xA0A load instruction flows down the pipe, reaches the memory stage, and finds it has to stall due to a structural hazard on the unified memory. \xA0Say this stall is due to the fetch stage, which is accessing the unified memory to fetch a new instruction. \xA0The load instruction in the memory stage depends on a resource being used in the fetch stage. \xA0If the fetch stage continues to access the memory on subsequent cycles, the load instruction in the memory stage is never able to access the resource and progress, thus deadlock occurs. \xA0To break the deadlock, the fetch stage may have to be notified of stalls in the memory stage due to a structural hazard on the unified memory and allow the load to progress by giving up the resource for a cycle. The point that is trying to be made here is that if an instruction causes a stall, and hence causes all instructions behind it in the pipeline to stall, it better be able to complete without any actions from instructions behind it. \xA0If the instruction causing the stall is unable to complete as it needs some action from an instruction behind it, a dependency cycle is present and deadlock occurs. Hope that helps.

Hope that helps.

An example of this situation is as follows: Lets say the architecture has a unified instruction and data memory. \xA0A load instruction flows down the pipe, reaches the memory stage, and finds it has to stall due to a structural hazard on the unified memory. \xA0Say this stall is due to the fetch stage, which is accessing the unified memory to fetch a new instruction. \xA0The load instruction in the memory stage depends on a resource being used in the fetch stage. \xA0If the fetch stage continues to access the memory on subsequent cycles, the load instruction in the memory stage is never able to access the resource and progress, thus deadlock occurs. \xA0To break the deadlock, the fetch stage may have to be notified of stalls in the memory stage due to a structural hazard on the unified memory and allow the load to progress by giving up the resource for a cycle. The point that is trying to be made here is that if an instruction causes a stall, and hence causes all instructions behind it in the pipeline to stall, it better be able to complete without any actions from instructions behind it. \xA0If the instruction causing the stall is unable to complete as it needs some action from an instruction behind it, a dependency cycle is present and deadlock occurs. Hope that helps.

The point that is trying to be made here is that if an instruction causes a stall, and hence causes all instructions behind it in the pipeline to stall, it better be able to complete without any actions from instructions behind it. \xA0If the instruction causing the stall is unable to complete as it needs some action from an instruction behind it, a dependency cycle is present and deadlock occurs. Hope that helps.
Upvotes:
1

Title: Linking forum posts -comparch-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
The prof. explains a hypothetical deadlock (basically a 'hang' situation) when the feed back travels back and forward in the pipeline i.e. a prev instruction (n) depends on the next instruction (n+1) and vice versa simultaneously. However I cannot think of any instruction where instr \xA0n would depend on instr n+1 its always the other way round i.e. instr n+1 depends on instr n. Maybe I am missing in understanding the deadlock situation? Anyone got this deadlock example?\xA0
Upvotes:
1
